etymologies: late 16th century: from medieval Latin regurgitat-, from the verb regurgitare, from Latin re- ‘again, back’ + gurges, gurgit- ‘whirlpool’

definitions: bring (swallowed food) up again to the mouth

examples.text: gulls regurgitate food for the chicks
the regurgitated remains of their meals

shortDefinitions: bring swallowed food up again to mouth

definitions: (of a fluid) flow through a vessel or valve in the body in a direction opposite to normal

examples.text: an incompetent mitral valve allows blood to regurgitate into the left atrium throughout ventricular contraction

shortDefinitions: flow through vessel or valve in body in direction opposite to normal

definitions: repeat (information) without analyzing or comprehending it

examples.text: facts that can then be regurgitated at examinations

shortDefinitions: repeat information without analysing or comprehending it
